titleStmt.title: William Morris to Thomas Pennant, 14 January 1756

list.item: The Double white peach leavd Campanula
Scarlet, white, & Hautboy Strawberis, the latter in fruit

div.p: It was this Day I received the Almanack inclos’d herewithThis may well have been an almanac published in Dublin, accessible by sea from William Morris's home in Holyhead. which is at your Service, the Continual Westerly Winds & Storms we have had for a Month past, hath Stopd. all Com˜unication between us & Dublin,For William Morris's comments on atrocious weather and the difficulties of communication with Dublin at the close of 1755, see his letter to Richard Morris, 31 December 1755, in ML, I, p. 397. & I don’t remember the Day when, I have been below high Water mark. the SokerThe reading is unclear but may possibly be related to the noun 'sucker', a young mamal, listed as having the figurative senses of 'simpleton' or 'one who draws profit or extorts subsistence from some sources' in the OED. It may in this case relate to an acquaintance of William Morris's, Siôn Owen, who helped him gather fossils and other objects of curiosity. sent me word that he had been at Llanddwyn point, but found nothing worth notice, phaps the Spring may prove more favvourable for Discoveries, I have found in the Wall of our CastrumWilliam Morris may here be referring to an area within the cemetery of St Cybi's Church at Holyhead, where square enclosure was left incomplete to enable ships could gain shelter from the sea. For Pennant's description of this location, see A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), II, p. 277. a Small Compressd TrochusA genus of gastropod molluscs. See OED. of abot. 3/10 of an Inch diameter, wch, I take to be its full growth, as none of a larger Size are to be seen here. will send ye: some Specimens anon. in hopes it may turn out to be one of those wanting phaps Tit. 9. And I think have met with Tit. 7 which I shall likewise send you. The French Conchyly.This may be a reference to the work of Antoine-Joseph Dézallier d'Argenville. His L'histoire naturelle éclaircie dans deux de ses parties principales, la lithologie et la conchyliologie, dont l'une traite des pierres et l'autre des coquillages was published in Paris in 1742, but a further work on conchylology, L'histoire naturelle, éclaircie dans une de ses parties principales, la conchyliologie, que traite des coquillages de mer, de riviere et de terre may not have appeared until 1757, also published at Paris. is now ready to be returnd, when a Safe conveyance offers: though he inveighs against ListerLister &c I think his method is far from being unexceptionable, as to Shells. however it’s a most Superbe performance, and I am greatly obliged to you for a Sight of it.

Notwithstanding the Storms we have had all winter, the Vegetable tribe (I mean plants & Shrubs) have Suffer’d less from Cold than ever I remember, you have on the other Side a list of Such Plants which are now in blow &c in my Little GardenCorroborating the evidence of this letter, William Morris refers at the beginning of February 1756 in a letter to his brother Richard to having 'y mis diweddaf oddeutu deugain math o lysiau a gwydd yn eu blodau ...' ('in the past month around forty types of plants and shrubs in flower'). See William Morris to Richard Morris, 4 February 1756, in ML, I, p. 402. Lists of plants in his gardens are also found in William Morris to Richard Morris, 26 October 1740, in ibid., pp. 38–40; and idem to idem, 26 July 1758, in ibid., II, p. 81. Further on William's activity as a gardener, see Dafydd Wyn Wiliam, Cofiant William Morris (1705–63) (Llangefni: Yr Awdur, 1995), pp. 133, 136.) – I wish you a Succession of Happy years & am

closer.salute:
Sir
your most obliged & most obedt.
humble Servt.

postscript.p:
P. S.
Messrs. Pennant and Lysons promisd me some Flowering Shrubs. but how to come at them I know not. Mr Lysons wanted somewhat out of my garden Qu. what?

It may be that the following Phænomenon was not observed in your Parts. Thus says my Diary. Jan˜y 1st. abot. 11ho½ A.M. I observed a white rainbow very entire and Distinct, without its being in the least tinged with any of the usual Colours vizt. Red Orange, yellow, &c but consisting only of Different shades of white there was not a Cloud to be seen & the Horizon Clear. It came in the Evening to be very Foggy & a heavy rain fell at night – Pray your remark hereon.
